column1:
The study was a randomized control trial designed to evaluate the effects of the Rent Reform Demonstration on earnings and employment for the District of Columbia Housing Authority in Washington, D.C. The authors used a statistical model to compare the outcomes of the treatment and control group members based on PHA administrative records and wage records obtained through the National Directory of New Hires. 

The D.C. PHA study sample included 1,909 households who were not elderly or disabled (as defined by HUD), were currently receiving housing choice vouchers, and were scheduled for recertification. 944 households were randomly assigned to the treatment group and were subject to the new rent policy for the duration of the demonstration. 965 households were assigned to the control group and were subject to the existing rent policies in place at the D.C. PHA. Heads of households were predominately female (91 percent), Black/African-American (97 percent), and 42 years old on average. ,"Employment

column2: The study found that employment and average quarterly employment were not significantly different across families in the new rent policy group and the comparison group.

column1: Earnings and Wages

column2: The study found that total earnings were not significantly different across the new rent policy group and the comparison group.

column1: Public Benefits Receipt

column2: The study found that the likelihood of remaining in the HCV program was not significantly different across the new rent policy group and the comparison group.

The study found that the new rent policy group had a statistically significant longer time that they received a housing subsidy compared to the comparison group at 30 months (0.6 months). However, the length of time receiving a housing subsidy was not significantly different across the groups in Year 1. ","Although the study was a well-implemented randomized controlled trial, there are a few factors that should be considered when interpreting the findings.

column1: The study authors estimated multiple related impacts on outcomes related to Employment, Earnings, and Public Benefits Receipt. Performing multiple statistical tests on related outcomes makes it more likely that some impacts will be found statistically significant purely by chance and not because they reflect program effectiveness. The authors did not perform statistical adjustments to account for the multiple tests, so the number of statistically significant findings in these domains is likely to be overstated.

Prior to the Rent Reform Demonstration, Washington, D.C. had instituted a biennial recertification schedule for working-age, nondisabled families. D.C. did not implement the 3-year recertification period and income-reporting requirements until after the 1st year of implementation for the new rent policy group. Thus, the authors suggest that the findings cannot represent the impact of the updated recertification period, which they assert as the most important policy change.

For the purposes of this report, the authors defined the follow-up period as “the period that begins in the month after the month in which the family’s new TTP was expected to take effect” and not from random assignment. A family’s new TTP effective date typically occurred 4 to 6 months after random assignment (in Quarter 3). Thus, Year 1 is defined as Quarters 3-6 after random assignment, and Year 2 is defined as Quarters 7-10 after random assignment. ",,,,"Absence of conflict of interest.  ",,"Urban, United States","Causal Impact Analysis","Adult, Low income","Employment and Training Services, Employment and Reemployment, Other employment and reemployment","Earnings and wages-Mod/high-No impacts, Employment-Mod/high-No impacts, Public benefits receipt-Mod/high-Favorable impacts",,"The federal Housing Choice Voucher program that provides rental subsidies to low-income families has been criticized for having a disincentive to work (due to policies that increase rent prices as family income rises) and for requiring substantial administrative costs and effort to implement. In 2015, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) launched the Rent Reform Demonstration to design and evaluate an alternative rent-subsidy policy for housing choice voucher recipients.

In Washington, DC the new Rent Reform Demonstration policy updated three main areas of the subsidy program: (1) how total tenant payments and subsidies are calculated, (2) recertification time periods, and (3) safeguards for families. First, the policy simplified how the total tenant payment (TTP) is calculated by basing it on gross income over the past 12 months (rather than adjusted income), ignoring income earned from total family assets less than $25,000, and linking utility allowances to voucher amounts. Additionally, a $75 minimum total tenant payment designed to mirror a typical landlord-tenant relationship was also implemented for the first time as part of the new rent policy. Second, annual income recertifications were replaced with a triennial recertification to ensure that that earnings gains do not increase TTP for at least two years. Finally, the new policy included additional safeguards for families. For example, the revised policy included a 6-month grace period to allow families to temporarily reduce their TTP after the triennial recertification if their current or expected income was lower than their income over the prior 12 months and allowed for the family to apply annually for interim recertifications when their income dropped by more than 10 percent. Additionally, the new policy included a revised hardship policy that allowed TTP reductions under specific conditions (e.g., when facing eviction).

The study served existing tenant-based housing choice voucher holder families that were not an elderly or disabled household (as defined by HUD). ","The study's objective was to examine the impact of the Rent Reform Demonstration on earnings and employment among families served by the Public Housing Authority (PHA) in Washington, DC. The authors also investigated similar research questions for each of the three other PHAs as separate contrasts and conducted a pooled analysis across all four sites, the profiles of which are available here:

column2: Lexington, KY
Louisville, KY
San Antonio, TX
All PHAs

The study was a randomized controlled trial that used PHA administrative data and wage records to compare families receiving housing choice vouchers who were subject to the new Rent Reform Demonstration rules to a comparison group subject to the existing rent rules of their PHA.

In Washington D.C., the study found that the families in the new rent policy group received a housing subsidy significantly longer than those in the existing rent rules group at 30 months. The study found that employment, average quarterly employment, total earnings, and likelihood of remaining in the HCV program were not significantly different across the new rent policy group and the comparison group.

The quality of causal evidence presented in this report is high because it was based on a well-implemented randomized controlled trial. This means we are confident that the estimated effects are attributable to the Rent Reform Demonstration, and not to other factors.  ","Riccio, J., & Deitch, V. (2019). The rent reform demonstration: Early effects on employment and housing subsidies. column1:
The study was a randomized control trial designed to evaluate the effects of the Rent Reform Demonstration on earnings and employment for the Louisville Metropolitan Housing Authority in Louisville, KY. The authors used a statistical model to compare the outcomes of the treatment and control group members based on PHA administrative records and wage records obtained through the National Directory of New Hires. 

The Louisville PHA study sample included 1,908 households who were not elderly or disabled (as defined by HUD), were currently receiving housing choice vouchers, and were scheduled for recertification. 947 households were randomly assigned to the treatment group and were subject to the new rent policy for the duration of the demonstration. 961 households were assigned to the control group and were subject to the existing rent policies in place at the Louisville PHA. Heads of households were predominately female (96 percent), Black/African-American (80 percent), and 39 years old on average. ,"Employment

column2: The study found that families in the new rent policy group were statistically significant more likely to be employed in all quarters than the comparison group (4.3 percentage points).

The study found that families in the new rent policy group were statistically significant less likely to have been employed at any point in the last three months in quarter 11, and had lower average quarterly employment in quarter 11 than the comparison group. However, the study found that employment in Year 1 (Quarters 3-6), Year 2 (Quarters 7-10), Years 1 and 2 combined (Quarters 3-10), and quarters 2 through 8 were not significantly different across the groups.

column1: Earnings and Wages

column2: The study found that the families in the new rent policy group had statistically significant lower total earnings in the seventh and eleventh quarters ($252 and $393 less, respectively) after random assignment. However, total earnings in Year 1 (Quarters 3-6), Year 2 (Quarters 7-10), Years 1 and 2 combined (Quarters 3-10), quarters 2 through 6, and quarter 8 were not significantly different across the groups.

column1: Public Benefits Receipt

column2: The study found that families in the new rent policy group were statistically significant more likely to remain in the HCV program than the comparison group after Year 1 and 30 months (3.4 and 8.2 percentage points, respectively).

The study found that the new rent policy group had a statistically significant longer time that they received a housing subsidy compared to the comparison group at Year 1 and 30 months (0.2 and 1.5 months longer, respectively).  ","Although the study was a well-implemented randomized controlled trial, there are a few factors that should be considered when interpreting the findings.

column1: The study authors estimated multiple related impacts on outcomes related to Employment, Earnings, and Public Benefits Receipt. Performing multiple statistical tests on related outcomes makes it more likely that some impacts will be found statistically significant purely by chance and not because they reflect program effectiveness. The authors did not perform statistical adjustments to account for the multiple tests, so the number of statistically significant findings in these domains is likely to be overstated.

Families in Louisville who were randomly assigned to the new rent policy were allowed to opt to continue to be subject to the existing rent rules. About 22 percent chose to continue to follow the existing rules, but are still in the new rent policy group for purposes of the evaluation. As such, the authors suggest that the estimated effects of the new rent policy in Louisville may be reduced.

For the purposes of this report, the authors defined the follow-up period as “the period that begins in the month after the month in which the family’s new TTP was expected to take effect” and not from random assignment. A family’s new TTP effective date typically occurred 4 to 6 months after random assignment (in Quarter 3). Thus, Year 1 is defined as Quarters 3-6 after random assignment, and Year 2 is defined as Quarters 7-10 after random assignment. ",,,,"Absence of conflict of interest.  ",,"Urban, United States","Causal Impact Analysis","Adult, Low income","Employment and Training Services, Employment and Reemployment, Other employment and reemployment","Earnings and wages-Mod/high-Unfavorable impacts, Employment-Mod/high-Mixed impacts, Public benefits receipt-Mod/high-Favorable impacts",,"The federal Housing Choice Voucher program that provides rental subsidies to low-income families has been criticized for having a disincentive to work (due to policies that increase rent prices as family income rises) and for requiring substantial administrative costs and effort to implement. In 2015, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) launched the Rent Reform Demonstration to design and evaluate an alternative rent-subsidy policy for housing choice voucher recipients.

In Louisville, the new Rent Reform Demonstration policy updated three main areas of the subsidy program: (1) how total tenant payments and subsidies are calculated, (2) recertification time periods, and (3) safeguards for families. First, the policy simplified how the total tenant payment (TTP) is calculated by basing it on gross income over the past 12 months (rather than adjusted income), ignoring income earned from total family assets less than $25,000, and linking utility allowances to voucher amounts. Additionally, a $50 minimum total tenant payment designed to mirror a typical landlord-tenant relationship was also implemented for the first time as part of the new rent policy. Second, annual income recertifications were replaced with a triennial recertification to ensure that that earnings gains do not increase TTP for at least two years. Finally, the new policy included additional safeguards for families. For example, the revised policy included a 6-month grace period to allow families to temporarily reduce their TTP after the triennial recertification if their current or expected income was lower than their income over the prior 12 months and allowed for the family to apply annually for interim recertifications when their income dropped by more than 10 percent. Additionally, the new policy included a revised hardship policy that allowed TTP reductions under specific conditions (e.g., when facing eviction).  ","The study's objective was to examine the impact of the Rent Reform Demonstration on earnings and employment among families served by the Public Housing Authority (PHA) in Louisville, Kentucky. The authors also investigated similar research questions for each of the three other PHAs as separate contrasts and conducted a pooled analysis across all four sites, the profiles of which are available here:

Washington, D.C.

All PHAs

The study was a randomized controlled trial that used PHA administrative data and wage records to compare families receiving housing choice vouchers who were subject to the new Rent Reform Demonstration rules to a comparison group subject to the existing rent rules of their PHA.

In Louisville, KY, the study found that families in the new rent policy group had significantly lower earnings in two quarters (7 and 11), were significantly more likely to remain in the HCV program, and received a housing subsidy significantly longer than those in the existing rent rules group. The study had mixed effects on quarterly employment.

The quality of causal evidence presented in this report is high because it was based on a well-implemented randomized controlled trial. column1:
The study was a randomized control trial designed to evaluate the effects of the Rent Reform Demonstration on earnings and employment for the Lexington-Fayette Urban County Housing Authority in Lexington, KY. The authors used a statistical model to compare the outcomes of the treatment and control group members based on PHA administrative records and wage records obtained through the National Directory of New Hires. 

The Lexington PHA study sample included 979 households who were not elderly or disabled (as defined by HUD), were currently receiving housing choice vouchers, and were scheduled for recertification. 486 households were randomly assigned to the treatment group and were subject to the new rent policy for the duration of the demonstration. 493 households were assigned to the control group and were subject to the existing rent policies in place at the Lexington Housing Authority. Heads of households were predominately female (97 percent), Black/African-American (81 percent), and 37 years old on average.,"Employment

column2: The study suggested a positive relationship between the Rent Reform Demonstration on ever being employed, being employed in all quarters, and average quarterly employment, but these relationships were not statistically significant.

column1: Earnings and Wages

column2: The study found that the new rent policy group had significantly higher total earnings ($353 more) in the eighth quarter after random assignment. However, total earnings in Year 1 (Quarters 3-6), Year 2 (Quarters 7-10), Years 1 and 2 combined (Quarters 3-10), and all other individual quarters were not significantly different across the groups.

column1: Public Benefits Receipt

column2: The study found that significantly more families in the new rent policy group remained in the HCV program than the comparison group (5.1 percent more).

The study did not find any statistically significant effects of the Rent Reform Demonstration on the length of time a household received a housing subsidy.  ","Although the study was a well-implemented randomized controlled trial, there are a few factors that should be considered when interpreting the findings.

column1: The study authors estimated multiple related impacts on outcomes related to Employment, Earnings, and Public Benefits Receipt. Performing multiple statistical tests on related outcomes makes it more likely that some impacts will be found statistically significant purely by chance and not because they reflect program effectiveness. The authors did not perform statistical adjustments to account for the multiple tests, so the number of statistically significant findings in these domains is likely to be overstated.

Lexington had already introduced a $150 minimum TTP before the demonstration began, with few exemptions permitted. The authors noted that because Lexington continued the policy for both the new rent policy and existing rent policy group, findings only reflect the other features of the new rent rules and not any possible effects of a minimum TTP.

For the purposes of this report, the authors defined the follow-up period as “the period that begins in the month after the month in which the family’s new TTP was expected to take effect” and not from random assignment. A family’s new TTP effective date typically occurred 4 to 6 months after random assignment (in Quarter 3). Thus, Year 1 is defined as Quarters 3-6 after random assignment, and Year 2 is defined as Quarters 7-10 after random assignment. ",,,,"Absence of conflict of interest.  ",,"Urban, United States","Causal Impact Analysis","Adult, Low income","Employment and Training Services, Employment and Reemployment, Other employment and reemployment","Earnings and wages-Mod/high-Favorable impacts, Employment-Mod/high-No impacts, Public benefits receipt-Mod/high-Favorable impacts",,"The federal Housing Choice Voucher program that provides rental subsidies to low-income families has been criticized for having a disincentive to work (due to policies that increase rent prices as family income rises) and for requiring substantial administrative costs and effort to implement. In 2015, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) launched the Rent Reform Demonstration to design and evaluate an alternative rent-subsidy policy for housing choice voucher recipients.

In Lexington, the new Rent Reform Demonstration policy updated three main areas of the subsidy program: (1) how total tenant payments and subsidies are calculated, (2) recertification time periods, and (3) safeguards for families. First, the policy simplified how the total tenant payment (TTP) is calculated by basing it on gross income over the past 12 months (rather than adjusted income), ignoring income earned from total family assets less than $25,000, and linking utility allowances to voucher amounts. A $150 minimum total tenant payment designed to mirror a typical landlord-tenant relationships was also implemented prior to when the demonstration began and continued to apply as part of the new rent policy. Second, annual income recertifications were replaced with a triennial recertification to ensure that that earnings gains do not increase TTP for at least two years. Finally, the new policy included additional safeguards for families. For example, the revised policy included a 6-month grace period to allow families to temporarily reduce their TTP after the triennial recertification if their current or expected income was lower than their income over the prior 12 months and allowed for the family to apply annually for interim recertifications when their income dropped by more than 10 percent. Additionally, the new policy included a revised hardship policy that allowed TTP reductions under specific conditions (e.g., when facing eviction).  ","The study's objective was to examine the impact of the Rent Reform Demonstration on earnings and employment among families served by the Public Housing Authority (PHA) in Lexington, Kentucky. The authors also investigated similar research questions for three other PHAs as separate contrasts and conducted a pooled analysis across all four sites, the profiles of which are available here:

column1:
The study used an interrupted time series design to compare changes in employment before and after the MPI program was implemented. The intervention time period is 2007–2017, the 11 years following the enactment of Connecticut’s MPI program. The comparison time period is the 11 years prior to MPI enactment: 1996–2006. 

Data comes from the Quarterly Census of Economics and Wages (QCEW) and Connecticut’s Department of Economic and Community Development. The author used a statistical model to compare the annual motion picture industry employment change before and after MPI program implementation, focusing on the immediate change and the average change over time. The statistical model controlled for some changes in state-specific factors like the average wages in the motion picture industry in Connecticut and some competitive factors like changes in other states’ MPI tax expenditures. ,"Employment

column2: The study suggested that there was a higher annual percentage point change in employment in Connecticut’s motion picture industry the first year after MPI program implementation compared to the average annual change in the 11 years previous but that there was no relationship between the MPI program and the average annual percentage point change in employment in this industry over time in Connecticut. ","Since the MPI program was only introduced at one point in time and was not introduced by the study author, we cannot be certain that the timing of the MPI program was unrelated to other contextual factors that might also have affected employment in the motion picture industry.",,,,"Absence of conflict of interest.","Industry, Arts, entertainment, and recreation","United States","Causal Impact Analysis",Adult,"Employment and Training Services, Employer Services, Other employer services","Employment-Low-Favorable impacts",,"Tax incentives specific to the motion picture industry began in the late-1990s and early-2000s but are part of a broader context of location-specific economic development incentives that began over a century ago. More than 30 states have an MPI program that offers corporate tax incentives and other services to encourage film and television production in their state. MPI programs target employment tied to the production of motion pictures, television programs and commercials, and videos. This study focused on MPI programs in states that offer particularly large MPI tax expenditures. Connecticut enacted an MPI program in 2006 and, between 2007 and 2017, and devoted $1 billion to this incentive program. ","The study’s objective was to examine the impact of the motion picture incentive (MPI) program on employment in the motion picture industry. The authors investigated similar research questions for four other states, the profiles of which can be found here:
New York
Louisiana
Georgia
Massachusetts

The study used an interrupted time series design to compare changes in employment before and after the MPI program was implemented. Data came from the Quarterly Census of Economics and Wages (QCEW) and Connecticut's Department of Economic and Community Development Annual Reports.

The study suggested that there was a higher annual percentage point change in Connecticut’s motion picture industry employment the first year after MPI program implementation compared to the average annual change in the 11 years previous.

The quality of causal evidence presented in this report is low because other time-varying factors could have influenced the outcome. This means we are not confident that the estimated effects are attributable to the MPI program; other factors are likely to have contributed. ","Thom, M. (2019). Do state corporate tax incentives create jobs? Quasi-experimental evidence from the entertainment industry. State and Local Government Review, 51(2), 92-103. [Connecticut]","Do state corporate tax incentives create jobs? Quasi-experimental evidence from the entertainment industry (Thom, 2019)","Study Type: Causal Impact Analysis",,,2019,https://doi.org/10.1177/0160323X19877232,"January 2023",,,"Low Causal Evidence","Interrupted Time Series Design","Systematic Annual Search and Review Protocol"

column1:
The study used an interrupted time series design to compare changes in employment before and after the MPI program was implemented. The intervention time period is 2006–2017, the 12 years following the enactment of Georgia’s MPI program. The comparison time period is the 12 years prior to MPI enactment: 1994–2005. 

Data comes from the Quarterly Census of Economics and Wages (QCEW) and Georgia’s Department of Audits and Accounts. The author used a statistical model to compare the annual motion picture industry employment change before and after MPI program implementation, focusing on the immediate change and the average change over time. The statistical model controlled for some changes in state-specific factors like the average wages in the motion picture industry in Georgia and some competitive factors like changes in other states’ MPI tax expenditures. ,"Employment

column2: The study suggested that there was no relationship between the MPI program and the annual percentage point change in employment in the motion picture industry either the first year after MPI program implementation or over time.   ","The annual change in employment in the motion picture industry in Georgia did not follow a stable trend prior to implementation of the MPI program. Additionally, since the MPI program was only introduced at one point in time, we cannot be certain that the timing of the MPI program was unrelated to other contextual factors that might also have affected employment in the motion picture industry. ",,,,"Absence of conflict of interest. ","Industry, Arts, entertainment, and recreation","United States","Causal Impact Analysis",Adult,"Employment and Training Services, Employer Services, Other employer services","Employment-Low-No impacts",,"Tax incentives specific to the motion picture industry began in the late-1990s and early-2000s but are part of a broader context of location-specific economic development incentives that began over a century ago. More than 30 states have an MPI program that offers corporate tax incentives and other services to encourage film and television production in their state. MPI programs target employment tied to the production of motion pictures, television programs and commercials, and videos. This study focused on MPI programs in states that offer particularly large MPI tax expenditures. Georgia enacted an MPI program in 2005 and, between 2006 and 2017, devoted $1.54 billion to this incentive program. ","The study’s objective was to examine the impact of the motion picture incentive (MPI) program on employment in the motion picture industry. The authors investigated similar research questions for four other states, the profiles of which can be found here:
New York
Louisiana
Connecticut
Massachusetts

The study used an interrupted time series design to compare changes in employment before and after the MPI program was implemented. Data came from the Quarterly Census of Economics and Wages (QCEW) and Georgia’s Department of Audits and Accounts.
The study suggested there was no relationship between the MPI program and changes in employment in the motion picture industry in Georgia.

The quality of causal evidence presented in this report is low because other time-varying factors could have influenced the outcome. This means we could not be confident that any estimated effects would be attributable to the MPI program; other factors are likely to have contributed. However, the study did not find statistically significant effects","Thom, M. (2019). Do state corporate tax incentives create jobs? Quasi-experimental evidence from the entertainment industry. column1:
The study used an interrupted time series design to compare changes in employment before and after the MPI program was implemented. The intervention time period is 2002–2017, the 16 years following the enactment of Louisiana’s MPI program. The comparison time period is the 11 years prior to MPI enactment: 1991–2001. 

Data comes from the Quarterly Census of Economics and Wages (QCEW) and the Louisiana Office of Entertainment Industry Development. The author used a statistical model to compare the annual motion picture industry employment change before and after MPI program implementation, focusing on the immediate change and the average change over time. The statistical model controlled for some changes in state-specific factors like the average wages in the motion picture industry in Louisiana and some competitive factors like changes in other states’ MPI tax expenditures,"Employment

column2: The study suggested that there was a positive relationship between the MPI program and the average annual percentage point change in employment in the motion picture industry over time but that there was not a significant impact of the MPI program the first year after implementation compared to the average annual change observed in the previous 11 years. ","The annual change in employment in the motion picture industry in Louisiana did not follow a stable trend prior to implementation of the MPI program. Since the MPI program was only introduced at one point in time and was not introduced by the study author, we cannot be certain that the timing of the program was unrelated to other contextual factors that might also have affected employment in the motion picture industry. Additionally, the author cautions that these findings should be interpreted with caution because fewer years of data were available pre-intervention than post-intervention which could affect the estimation model.  ",,,,"Absence of conflict of interest. ","Industry, Arts, entertainment, and recreation","United States","Causal Impact Analysis",Adult,"Employment and Training Services, Employer Services, Other employer services","Employment-Low-Favorable impacts",,"Tax incentives specific to the motion picture industry began in the late-1990s and early-2000s but are part of a broader context of location-specific economic development incentives that began over a century ago. More than 30 states have an MPI program that offers corporate tax incentives and other services to encourage film and television production in their state. MPI programs target employment tied to the production of motion pictures, television programs and commercials, and videos. This study focused on MPI programs in states that offer particularly large MPI tax expenditures. Louisiana enacted an MPI program in 2002 and, between 2002 and 2017, devoted $2.29 billion to this incentive program, the second most of any state. ","The study’s objective was to examine the impact of the motion picture incentive (MPI) program on employment in the motion picture industry. The authors investigated similar research questions for four other states, the profiles of which can be found here:
New York
Connecticut
Georgia
Massachusetts

The study used an interrupted time series design to compare changes in employment before and after the MPI program was implemented. Data came from the Quarterly Census of Economics and Wages (QCEW) and the Louisiana Office of Entertainment Industry Development.

The study suggested that there was a positive relationship between MPI program implementation and the average annual percentage point change in employment in the motion picture industry in Louisiana over time. There was no evidence of an immediate impact in the annual change in employment in the first year of the program compared to the average annual change in the 11 prior years.

The quality of causal evidence presented in this report is low because other time-varying factors could have influenced the outcome. This means we are not confident that the estimated effects are attributable to the MPI program; other factors are likely to have contributed.","Thom, M. (2019).
